title: What will be the end-of-day closing value for the U.S. dollar against the Chinese yuan on 13 November 2020?
preds: I see very little chance of the exchange rate breaking out of the status quo of between 6 and 7 CNY. The exchange rate has not dipped below 6 in recent memory, and while it had exceeded 7 as recently as earlier this year, obviously a lot has happened between the US and China in the past several months, accelerated by the spread of COVID-19 that has only worsened the US-China relationship and caused a mass rethinking of global trade and global supply chains. With the election of Biden, who may have a more practical approach to the important relationship than his predecessor, there may be some room for upward movement in the exchange rate, but anything significant seems highly unlikely.

As of 11/7, 1USD equals 6.61 Chinese Yuan. Since July 2016, the maximum weekly change in the exchange rate was 0.176 Yuan, the average weekly change in the exchange rate was 0.0014 Yuan, and the minimum weekly change in the exchange rate was -0.116 Yuan.   To reach 7 Yuan, the exchange rate would have to increase more than twice the maximum weekly growth observed since mid-2016.  To reach 6 Yuan, the the exchange rate would have to decrease more than 5 times the maximum weekly decline observed since mid-2016. In April, there were rumors China's central bank would unofficially peg the Yuan to the US dollar so it would fluctuate "around 7 yuan in future" (https://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3079243/coronavirus-china-re-pegging-yuan-us-dollar-avert-financial)   The Yuan could devalue to 7 if another significant economic shock occurs, war with the US occurs, or the chinese government devalues their currency in order to increase exports.  All of which seem very unlikely, but theoretically possible.  I do not think China would want to cause problems with the US when going through a presidential transition and China signed a trade deal with the US in January that included a provision prohibiting competitive currency depreciation.
Biden taking Michigan. Plus China has done some pretty aggressive things reigning in the Ant financial IPO, making me think that they don't want meaningful FX weakness during this period as well.
Trump doing well in some of the early polling, RMB selling off a bit. I don't think they will let it through 7, but raising odds a bit.

It is almost inconceivable that the Dollar-Yuan ratio would be above 8, since it has not been that high since 2006. Additionally, the ratio has not been below 6 since 2018, even with the recent downswings. After the US election the Yuan will likely either go up if Biden wins or down if Trump wins. It seems a little more likely that Biden will win, so I would imagine that the Yuan will stay between 6 and 7, but it could push up above 7.

According to Bloomberg, in the past 5-years the yuan has not dipped below CNY 6 nor has it risen above CNY 7.(1) While Trump, who will still be in office on Nov 13 regardless of the election outcome, has vowed to hold China accountable for its role in the COVID crisis I think it unlikely that he will attempt to renew the trade war with China given the current fixation on domestic issues. Accordingly, I think the yuan will remain stable between its current valuation of 6-7 CNY. References 1.  Bloomberg, 2020. “USD-CNY X-RATE”. Retrieved from https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/USDCNY:CUR

The comparatively high probability for 7-8 stems from the possibility of a global risk-off episode (due to new lockdowns and/or a contested US election) inducing a USD-rally, pushing the CNY/USD slightly above 7 (similar to earlier this year).

US government and EU are trying to increase the value of the yuan to reduce the competitive advantage of China on the world market, while China is trying to do the opposite. With the US involved in their election process beyond November 13, we expect the currency to roughly remain constant. When running a time series analysis, there is roughly a 90% probability that the currency value will remain in its current 6-7 CNY bracket. As the currency value is closer to the bracket above (i.e. 7-8), we estimate that there is a higher chance that it will move up rather than down.

6.5 Chinese yuan to 1 U.S. Dollar will  be the end of the day closing value. 6.5 is an approximate average. However, it has been lower and higher in the last decade but not by much more than +/- .01    *Note: One thing you must understand about currency is where you are spending the currency is its actual value. one of many cites:
https://www.exchangerates.org.uk/USD-CNY-exchange-rate-history.html

This determination will be based solely on research and information that I deem trustworthy. In no way shape or form do I come close to qualifying as a sound forecaster on this particular topic. From an objective outlook, the Chinese yuan has been in steady decline since May 2020.  According to the BBC, “China’s currency has weakened to its lowest point in more than a decade, prompting the US to label Beijing a currency manipulator. The escalation of the trade war, sparked by fresh U.S. tariff threats, is seen to have prompted the policy shift” (BBC, 2019). What is the impact of a weaker yuan? “A weaker yuan makes Chinese exports more competitive, or cheaper to buy with foreign currencies. From the U.S. perspective, it is seen as an attempt to offset the impact of higher tariffs on Chinese imports coming into America. A weaker yuan will also make imports into China more expensive, potentially driving up inflation and creating strains in its already slowing economy, as well as pushing currency holders to invest in other assets” (BBC, 2019). What’s next for the yuan? “Analysts forecast the yuan will weaken further. Oanda market strategist Edward Moya said continued yuan depreciation “should be expected” and we could “see another 5% before the end of the year”. Capital Economics now expects the yuan to end the year at 7.30 per U.S. dollar, compared with previous forecasts of 6.90” (BBC, 2019).

What will be the end-of-day closing value for the U.S. dollar against the Chinese yuan on 13 November 2020?
This is a very difficult moment in history. The pandemic has had severe impact on human life, with more than 200,000 Americans dying from COVID-19 or COVID-19 complications. The United States and the rest of the world are in times of uncertainty, which has individual citizens as well as major corporations concerned; “roughly half of all companies in the S&P 500 index have withdrawn earnings guidance, noted Donald Calcagni, chief investment officer with Mercer Advisors, and ‘the few who haven’t, are afraid to” (Riquier, 2020). The world is at a crossroads of what to do. 
Even with uncertainty, there is a fair amount of data for the U.S. dollar against the Chinese yuan. According to the stock and research company, Macrotrends, the U.S. dollar has had a consistent value compared to the Chinese yuan. From 2008 through the present, the exchange rate of Chinese Yuan to the U.S. Dollar has been valued, at the years close, between 6.00 to 7.00. Even with a worldwide pandemic, the data is consistent. I am 98% sure that at the end of the year, the U.S. dollar and Chinese yuan exchange rate will be between 6.00 to 7.00. The final 2% is between 7.00 to 8.00. 
Trading Economics. (2020). Currencies. Trading Economics. Retrieved from:  https://tradingeconomics.com/forecast/currency
Macrotrends. (2020). Dollar Yuan Exchange Rate-35 Year Historical Chart. Macrotrends. Retrieved from: https://www.macrotrends.net/2575/us-dollar-yuan-exchange-rate-historical-chart
Riguier, A. (2020, July 10). Forget earnings season. What’s the rest of 2020 going to look like. Market Watch. Retrieved from: https://www.marketwatch.com/story/forget-earnings-season-whats-the-rest-of-2020-going-to-look-like-2020-07-04

The Chinese economy has grown significantly in recent years driving the use of the yuan abroad (Tan, 2020). Three areas where the US dollar is defeats the yuan are stability, liquidity, and security, driving the dollar to continue to be the worlds foremost currency (Amadeo, 2020) Throughout summer 2020 in which the US economy fell due to the Covid-19 pandemic, a rise in the yuan to dollar exchange from 7.01 to 6.7 was observed (Macrotrends, 2020). Currently well within the 6.0 -7.0 range at 6.6947 as of 09:30 on 10/11/ 2020, average daily variances are well below 0.1% (Bloomberg, 2020). Therefore, with the exception of a large unforeseen market shift, current trends indicate that shifting out of the 6.0-7.0 range would take months (Bloomberg, 2020).  https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/02/outlook-for-china-yuan-and-the-us-dollar-amid-tech-war-trade.html https://www.thebalance.com/dollar-to-yuan-conversion-and-history-3306089 https://www.macrotrends.net/2575/us-dollar-yuan-exchange-rate-historical-chart https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/USDCNY:CUR

The closing value for the USD against the CNY has steadily decreased over the last 6 months and is has been resting at approximately 6.79 for since the beginning of October. It has not been above 7.00 since July 2020. A combination of the presidential election coming up, the holidays, and increasing COVID restriction, I do not think the USD will strengthen until the spring against the CNY. However, I would say there is a chance that it could go up above 7.00. However, this depends on public opinion during and immediately following the elections and public outlook on the U.S. economy at that time. If people are feeling positive post-election and going into the holiday season, stock prices could go up and drive up the value of the USD.  Therefore, I give a 78% chance that the USD against the CNY will remain between 6.00 and 7.00 and a 22% it will fall between 7.00 and 8.00 on November 13th 2020.  https://www.exchangerates.org.uk/USD-CNY-exchange-rate-history.html https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/USDCNY=X/?guccounter=1&guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&guce_referrer_sig=AQAAACkKahSfohWJ1BPCjQmXo8rNmUTxi9seGzJl0eAupZ36RIjzZFHZ9mpMAah1ywnxQZwTo0_4Bfyw1atfwqUNkhRxBMDKyLTuu2G4Aczp49HM-jELR-SnFWgwwAsBrT6pgh1dO3AQ3vOAJw-9oF39vFHooASEtjw6ExTyKOyY3l1W

US trade deficit of August 2020 was about 67bn USD, the highest since 2008 and the third-highest on record. It seems Trumponomics don't really root out that very problem, not even with a trade war.
Not to mention the budget deficit - I heard congress glued together some form of preliminary budget until end of 2020.
The double deficit issue is back on the agenda, and it's apparently worse than ever.
However, my rationale is that with markets getting increasingly nervous and volatile over the next two weeks, investors will be looking for a shelter for capital - the US Dollar will increasingly appear as a safe and stable haven, a pattern that has been repeatedly observed in past crises. As absurd as it factually is. USDCNY/01 November 2020: 6.98 est.
USDCNY/13 November 2020: 7.11 est.

The Chinese yuan has not gone below 6 since 2003 and it is not likely to. In the same time period the last time the yuan was greater that 7 to 1 was in March 2008 which was before the 2008 recession where the global GDP declined by 5.1%. There were additional points where the yuan was valued over 7 to 1 recently and we are now on a trend heading back down towards 6 to 1.

The current value of the U.S. dollar (USD) against the Chinese yuan is 1 USD to 6.79 yuan. (XE, 2020). In the past year, the yuan has fluctuated between 7.15 and 6.75, meaning it is only slightly below its highest value. COVID seems to have little impact on the value of the yuan, which gained 0.1 against the dollar in the first week of March (XE, 2020). It is surprising that the yuan has been so stable, considering recent actions against Huawei and general global resentment against China for the coronavirus.  In fact, in the last ten years, it has only fluctuated between 6.05 and 7.15, its lowest value (which occurred in May of this year). That doesn’t seem like much, but consider how China can move its currency to, for example, negate the effect of tariffs: “The recent decline in the value of the yuan largely nullifies the threatened tariff. Here’s the basic math: If a US importer buys $100 worth of goods from China when the exchange rate is 6.3 yuan to the dollar, that’s 630 yuan. If the exchange rate changes to 7, as it just did, then the US importer only needs $90 for the same purchase. If that import is then subject to a 10 percent tariff, the two cancel each other out and the cost to the importer remains basically the same.” (Karabell, 2019) Having said that, no recent tariffs have been put into effect, and there seems to be nothing for China to respond to via monetary policy at the present. The period of prediction is only ten days as of this writing.  Given the yuan is near its highest value, it is more likely to decline than to rise.  In the last week, the difference between the high and low of the yuan is 0.06.  I believe the closing value of the yuan on 13 November will be 1 USD to 6.85 yuan, with a confidence level of 40% at that mark.  A result of 6.75 to 6.95 has a confidence level of 90%. Works Cited: Karabell, Z. (2019, August 7). Listen, here’s why the value of China’s yuan really matters. 
Wired. https://www.wired.com/story/listen-value-chinas-yuan-really-matters/ XE (2020). USD to CNY Chart. https://www.xe.com/currencycharts/?from=USD&to=CNY

The value of the yuan has seen the impact from an escalation in the protracted U.S.-Sino trade war, as well as an adjustment and the impact of the ongoing tensions within Hong Kong.  At some point, and if the Chinese market ever become more transparent, I would expect to see the yuan drop again. We’re waiting to see the next yuan adjustment. The most emergent impact with be the upcoming U.S. election.  Either result will have a direct impact on closing value.  If it is a Biden victory I would expect a rise in yuan value as the Chinese will expect a “friendlier” administration.  I have no doubt the Biden administration will roll over on all trade wars and have “open-arms” to Chinese business.  I see this as a long-term disaster regarding U.S. security.   
I may not agree with several of the Trump administration policies, but I do agree on his position with regards to China.   If it is a Trump victory then I expect the value to remain the same or drop in anticipation of the prolonged trade war and heightened military engagements in the South China Sea.  
I believe that China doesn’t want to see a breach of 7 level.   IF that level is breached that could mean an indicator of the yuan weakness in the global economy.
Another factor is what’s happening in Hong Kong.  As the tensions continue it will cause a high degree of anxiety and uncertainty which could be bearing on prices. We’re seeing a lot of risk averse moves which will also impact the value of the yuan,

Assuming 5% annualized volatility implies about an 8% chance of a move from here. Doubling that probability somewhat since you could see wider outcomes around the election, in particular with a skew toward dollar strength.
Almost two month left; on the FX market this is ages for things to change. The post-November 3rd phase (last 10 days) will be very thrilling.

The currency exchange has marked the current value of 1 USD = 6.7802 CNY. The value of the CNY has been on the decrease but has been hanging between 6.000 and 7.000 since July with ups and downs. I believe that the election will play a major role if the value of the CNY increases or decreases.
I believe there is sizable tail risk to the USDCNH breaking above 7.00, mainly through a further escalation of tensions. The outcome of the US elections will be a major driver to this.
Has been below 7 for ~6 weeks now.
Consistently below 7. @bobrown is right about the money printing by the Fed having an effect. In addition the trade friction and some worldwide push back to the Chinese is also having an effect.

seasonal, bell-curves in the fall/winter.  While they differed slightly year to year, generally, this seemed a significant trend to consider in my forecast.  We have not seen a decrease below CNY 6 in the last 5 years.  Even though the current trend is sloping downward, historically, the right side of the bell-curve has happened after Nov 1.  Further, the forecast looks like it might be leveling out over the last couple weeks.

Observando el grafico de Yuan vs Dolar disponible por Google, podemos notar que históricamente en los últimos años el valor se encuentra estancado entre 6-7 yuan/dolar por lo que corresponde asignarle la mayor probabilidad a este tramo, la cual es muy posible siguiendo los patrones históricos.
Por otro lado, de igual forma un par de veces el precio ha estado sobre 7 yuan/dolar por lo que asigno un 15% de probabilidad a que se ubique en esta posición, pero de igual forma es una probabilidad baja, ya que en tan poco tiempo tendencia que ocurrir algún suceso importante para que existiera una subida de este calibre del precio yuan/dolar.
Por otro lado, existe una probabilidad baja de que el dolar se devalúe y el valor sea de 6 o menos, esto ya que China se encuentra liderando la búsqueda de la vacuna contra el covid en comparación con USA, entonce la creación de esta generaría una alza del valor Chino comparado con el Estadounidense. Además, China se encuentra en transición a su moneda virtual, por lo que también generaría un mayor movimiento económico y subiría el valor del Yuan. Pongo poca probabilidad ya que es poco tiempo hasta el 12 de noviembre y es muy difícil una baja de este nivel, pero es pequeñamente posible. Bibliografia:
https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-51483218
google yuan vs dolar
At 6.89 now. Unlikely to go  up
The Fed is printing money like there is no tomorrow. PBC is restrained in its money creation. The result is plain to see.
USD devaluation from money printing fiscal stimulus.
Close. If phase one of deal with US is implemented will the Yuan go up? Trade war is considered a drag on the Yuan.
The dollar is doing all the work erroding away. The Fed has set their course - more of the same, inflation is not an issue and won't be even when it is. Hang on folks this may have a ways to go.

Too close to line. Have to track longer to go all in  on bin 2. It is true that due to trade war the yuan has weakened. (Currency Manipulation?) It was just announced US-China will go ahead with phase 1 trade agreement. Will that matter? Agree Fed policy could have an effect but the Fed is not going to change interest rates.
The dollar continues to errode. Note that the close date is after the US election. Will the result have an impact on the currency? Likely the Fed's actions have more weight, however.
The dollar continues to errode due to a disfunctional government.
The dollar has eroded so quickly due to poor leadership.

The relevant financial market quote for this question in my opinion is the Renminbi futures contract for January and not the cash rate, as it best reflects market forces like interest rate difference.
https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/fx/emerging-market/chinese-renminbi.html Therefore, 7-8 is already (ever so slightly) in the money.  Additionally, a lot of dollar weakness and easing of global financial condition has happened without the Yuan gaining much ground. This does not bode well going forward, as the Fed has arguably front-loaded easing and the PBOC is playing a long game and still has a lot of powder kept dry for further easing in the third and fourth quarter. Therefore, I am revising my forecast to reflect "bearishness" for the Yuan that is maybe not justified by the cash rate but feels like the better play for this question.
Dropping down closer to the crowd, as there has been no movement in the last 2 years above 8 [1].  [1] https://www.xe.com/currencycharts/?from=USD&to=CNY&view=1Y
The dollar is dropping like a stone, propelled by lack of a crisis manager advised by greedy fossils.

Something to watch: Once the U.S. cuts the supply of U.S. dollars to Hong Kong, the latter's foreign exchange reserves will dry out to the point that its linked exchange rate system can no longer function, causing the Hong Kong dollar to depreciate as well as the Renminbi. When this happens, foreign companies will withdraw from the Special Administrative Region with their capital.
The dollar is quickly erroding as more is pumped into the system to keep the ship afloat.
This may be more about an erroding dollar than an strengthening reminbi.
The dollar is erroding as we spend spend and continue leaderless in the pandemic. The cost of a poor leader hits everyone in the pocket eventually.

The Yuan continues to be supported by the equity bull market in China and a generally more gloomy outlook for the US Dollar. The Financial Times ran articles on the reasons for dollar weakness on Monday and today (https://www.ft.com/content/e6352387-5704-4e44-9b79-22ae87039e59) arguing that the risks in the US outweigh:
- unemployment benefits may not be extended after July, which could crush the US economy
- Covid-19 is spreading quickly and does not seem to get under control before winter flu season
- Election year and risks associated with democratic horse trading in case of a victory
- Lack of demand for dollar swap facility by other central banks
A lot of bearish coverage can sometimes be a sign of a turnaround, but currently there are no signs that bets against the dollar are getting crowded..

This will be close. 
Gotta brush up on my Elliott Wave reading.

(incidentally this hovers around the consensus and I really can't disagree.)
If I need to adjust, I'd lean toward 7+

First quick and dirty forecast based on the time evolution over the last few years.
I'll follow @Tim-Zhou and @anthony-keene and tighten my forecast to be in the middle of theirs. Maybe one of us will be right.
I think by the time November hits China will be better prepared to handle covid fall out in terms of its economy.  In addition the US will be suffering from additional unrest that weakens the dollar.

China will look to strengthen its hand in the negotiations plus with covid 19 biting into us purchasing power will need to make its good more attractive will balancing against not going to far against the us

By the end of summer we will see a deflationary spike. Markets will crash along with most other assets classes. Cash will be king. The USD will spike and global currencies will be debased against the dollar. We may have another Breton Woods shortly there after
It's at 7.14 now.  China controls COVID,  US is not. US is printing money like crazy. So the likely range is 6-7, if not  6 or less
China likely to try to stay close to 7, but the dollar is softening, so the ratio may overshoot.

May 30= 7.1364CNY/$ In the last 5 years it's gone from a high of 6.2 to a low of 7.16. Since the onset of the pandemic it has gone from a high of 6.86 to the low of 7.16. It appears to be managed lower in response to the pandemic and the desire to increase exports. My assumption is that China would prefer a band around 7 and above to encourage exports to keep factories busy as they recover.

Since the value of the CNY is determined by the Chinese gov't, and is "allowed to float in a narrow margin around a fixed base rate determined with reference to a basket of world currencies" [1], it seems like this is more a question of how China wants to be perceived against the US in the fall or if there is a trading advantage to a stronger / weaker currency. Currently it is trading around 7 CNY to the USD [2].  I am going to bet that with the US election coming up, we may see an escalation in the trade war activity, with China devaluing the CNY in response. Any changes back to a "normal" rate won't happen until after January 20th 2021 (with a new US administration) or later if the US keeps-on keeping on with the current. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renminbi
[2] https://www.xe.com/currencycharts/?from=USD&to=CNY&view=1Y
country on fire, $ on fire? I can't see how this will not go down?

There is A LOT that needs to/will happen in the very near future to influence this... considering 7 was the previous long-standing high water mark/resistance level, we can expect a near coin toss as to how the valuation travels from here.
Do you get in a pissing match with India? Who develops the first C19 vaccine? How are C19 vaccines distributed? How do you walk back or double down on the stripping of Hong Kong's autonomy? When does Elon Musk release his next EDM single? etc. etc. etc. 
Only time will tell.

In times of financial stress, the US Dollar used to appreciate (counter-intuitively) versus major currencies in the world due to a "safe-haven" argument and because financial markets' liquidity is an important argument for speculative investors. On the other hand, China has a track record for administrating their currency within a bandwidth and most of the time weakening their currency (currency manipulation) verbally in order to make products more competitive on export markets. The total effect may be around zero.
With a special situation of an ongoing tariff war and an unprecedented increment in US public debt, (probably) slowing growth in China's currency reserves and not least disruptions in world trade/repatriation of some production in the wake of SARS-CoV-2, the total effect on USDCNY is hard to tell.
To me it depends on whether "the West" will continue to gather behind the US with one accord despite political tensions with the current White House administration (POTUS 45) in the future, and how hard the landing of the Chinese export oriented economic model and the distress in the Chinese financial system will turn out.
My guess is (armed conflicts with Chinese involvement excluded), the CNY will further depreciate by between 5 to 10 per cent, with a final exchange rate of about  7,60 CNY per USD on 13 November 2020.
